{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3574836,"name":"John Guzauckas","username":"johnguzauckas","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/j/cab0a1/{size}.png","created_at":"2025-03-31T13:44:44.695Z","cooked":"

We’ve recently tried to switch from Megatag to Megatag 2 with our Limelight 3G, and while we have it functioning at a basic level, I feel like there is something we are missing in terms of how the robot sets itself up before a match starts.

The core of the question revolves around the Pigeon 2’s yaw reading being accurate to the actual rotation of the robot on the field, as it’s what we pass in to the Limelight to use for Megatag 2 processing.

We are using the CTRE Swerve generated template with SDS modules and a Pigeon 2 as our gyro. Right now, when the drivetrain is constructed upon boot, it sets the yaw for the Pigeon 2 to “0”. In order for this to work on the field, we carefully place the robot on the field against either the nearest or furthest sides of the reef, or the driver’s station wall as being the most consistent options available and face it away from the drivers station. Then we turn the robot on, wait until it finishes booting, so that the pigeon is zeroed, and then move it to our autonomous starting location and start the match from there.

We knew, even when we came up with this strategy, that this is not typical of robots on the field. We are trying to figure out how to properly zero the pigeon without needing to depend so heavily on this setup, and instead just placing it for our auto (as precisely as we can), like other teams seem to do.

I’ve seen threads tha talk about how we should be using PathPlanner to seed our odometry at the beginning of auto, which we are, but my understanding is that this doesn’t zero the pigeon, it just helps the drivetrain determine its offsets from the Pigeon’s measurements for its rotation pose. So this would result in our Limelight having the wrong orientation for Megatag 2, and therefore would have bad pose estimations from the Limelight.

Is the correct solution for this to just place our robot for auto, know what angle that is relative to “forward” for field-centric, and modify our start-up routine to set the pigeon to that angle instead of 0? For example, if the robot starts auto facing the alliance wall, we use 180 degrees instead of 0 when we are “zeroing” it.

Our entire repository is public, but here are a couple of snippets of the things we are doing:

  • This is an example of us zeroing the pigeon in our drivetrain constructor
  • This is how we are updating the robot orientation for the Limelight

Trouble","clicks":0}],"read":true,"user_title":null,"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":70468,"hidden":false,"trust_level":1,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":""},"post_url":"/t/properly-setting-gyro-yaw-when-robot-is-being-placed-on-the-field/497523/1","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null,"can_vote":false},{"id":3574864,"name":"Jake Garlits","username":"iBleedBlue48","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/ibleedblue48/{size}/251462_2.png","created_at":"2025-03-31T14:06:46.510Z","cooked":"

We knew, even when we came up with this strategy, that this is not typical of robots on the field.

I would not agree with this being the case for robots using systems where consistent gyro angle is critical for their vision/alignment. I do not have a massive dataset for comparison, but in Indiana, all 3 of the top EPA robots (868, 7457, 1501) use this method of starting their robot aligned with the reef, then moving it to its auto position after getting its initial angle.

By ALWAYS zeroing the robot on the reef, you are eliminating potential yaw error by trying to guess what your initial yaw is. I do not think there is anything wrong with what you are doing, and I do not think there is any reason to try to change.

EDIT: Also, make sure you know that a yaw of 0 should always correlate to the front of the robot facing the RED alliance drive stations. This is critical for getting proper MegaTag2 poses.

EDIT 2: Also, you do not need to directly interface with the Pigeon2 when setting and reading yaw. The line you have commented out:

LimelightHelpers.SetRobotOrientation(ll, drivetrain.getState().Pose.getRotation().getDegrees(), 0, 0, 0, 0, 0);

is the correct way to send the LL the current yaw, and inside of your CTRE swerve subsystem, you can just use:

resetRotation(new Rotation2d(0));

to “zero” your yaw. Please note that Rotation2d() takes rotation values in radians, not degrees.

","post_number":2,"post_type":1,"posts_count":8,"updated_at":"2025-03-31T14:25:58.206Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":3,"reads":168,"readers_count":167,"score":83.6,"yours":false,"topic_id":497523,"topic_slug":"properly-setting-gyro-yaw-when-robot-is-being-placed-on-the-field","display_username":"Jake Garlits","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":3,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":2}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":27417,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"FRC 1501 Java Mentor / Alumni"},"post_url":"/t/properly-setting-gyro-yaw-when-robot-is-being-placed-on-the-field/497523/2","custom_user_title":"FRC 1501 Java Mentor / Alumni","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":1},{"id":"point_up","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":2,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3575060,"name":"Martin Nemaric","username":"Martini159","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/m/278dde/{size}.png","created_at":"2025-03-31T16:25:21.005Z","cooked":"

Here’s what we did:

Upon initialization (or at least, as soon as the Limelights initialize) we get a good Megatag 1 reading from two AprilTags (seen through a single Limelight), grab the Pose2d estimate from that, then actually SET our gyro to be whatever angle the vision is telling us we are at.

If mt1 is our Pose2d pose estimate from our Limelight, for our gyro, we did…

m_gyro.setGyroAngle(IMUAxis.kZ, mt1.getRotation().getDegrees());
","post_number":3,"post_type":1,"posts_count":8,"updated_at":"2025-03-31T16:25:21.005Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":2,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":2,"reads":115,"readers_count":114,"score":38.0,"yours":false,"topic_id":497523,"topic_slug":"properly-setting-gyro-yaw-when-robot-is-being-placed-on-the-field","display_username":"Martin Nemaric","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"reply_to_user":{"id":27417,"username":"iBleedBlue48","name":"Jake Garlits","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/ibleedblue48/{size}/251462_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":56673,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"post_url":"/t/properly-setting-gyro-yaw-when-robot-is-being-placed-on-the-field/497523/3","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3575130,"name":"Emil","username":"GronkBaby","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/g/ba8739/{size}.png","created_at":"2025-03-31T17:08:04.247Z","cooked":"

We would get it good enough using the starting line as our horizontal line to line it up with, and then we can rotate the bot to where we want it to be. Then every time we score, if we are close enough to the reef tag, it resets the gyro using the rotation from MT1, so essentially that initial little error that we have when putting our robot on the field does not matter.

We place ours against the sidewall to zero, then position. Same idea, really.

","post_number":5,"post_type":1,"posts_count":8,"updated_at":"2025-03-31T17:12:10.205Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":93,"readers_count":92,"score":18.6,"yours":false,"topic_id":497523,"topic_slug":"properly-setting-gyro-yaw-when-robot-is-being-placed-on-the-field","display_username":"John Hascall (he)","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":46267,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"Opinions expressed are mine only"},"post_url":"/t/properly-setting-gyro-yaw-when-robot-is-being-placed-on-the-field/497523/5","custom_user_title":"Opinions expressed are mine only","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3575148,"name":"Harrison","username":"hjmcphail76","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/hjmcphail76/{size}/234713_2.png","created_at":"2025-03-31T17:15:04.161Z","cooked":"

We use this method, and while it is annoying it actually gets us into a routine. We place, turn on, wait until LEDs flash (code starts), (also just wait about 30-0 sec.) Then we move the robot again, and finally manually pull the claw up from where it initializes. (Due to letting encoders initialize at a hard stop, and we do not have limit switches )

We’re doing the same thing. The advantage is that it makes for a really fast setup on the field. The disadvantage is that it doesn’t seem like the accuracy is as good as aligning to the side of the field. It might be out by a couple degrees.

","post_number":7,"post_type":1,"posts_count":8,"updated_at":"2025-03-31T18:25:40.643Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":3,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":78,"readers_count":77,"score":15.6,"yours":false,"topic_id":497523,"topic_slug":"properly-setting-gyro-yaw-when-robot-is-being-placed-on-the-field","display_username":"Scott W","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","reply_to_user":{"id":56673,"username":"Martini159","name":"Martin Nemaric","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/m/278dde/{size}.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":50699,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":""},"post_url":"/t/properly-setting-gyro-yaw-when-robot-is-being-placed-on-the-field/497523/7","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3575303,"name":"Benjamin Hall","username":"bhall-ctre","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/bhall-ctre/{size}/198180_2.png","created_at":"2025-03-31T18:54:13.382Z","cooked":"
johnguzauckas:

I’ve seen threads tha talk about how we should be using PathPlanner to seed our odometry at the beginning of auto, which we are, but my understanding is that this doesn’t zero the pigeon, it just helps the drivetrain determine its offsets from the Pigeon’s measurements for its rotation pose. So this would result in our Limelight having the wrong orientation for Megatag 2, and therefore would have bad pose estimations from the Limelight.

From what I can tell, most teams that set the standard deviation of the theta component to a fairly large value (since heading from vision is less trustworthy than from your IMU), and practically infinity with Megatag 2. In that case, the pose estimate’s heading (getState().Pose.getRotation()) can be used for the Limelight robot orientation since it’s mostly (if not entirely) derived from odometry instead of vision.

If you really need to use the Pigeon 2 yaw directly (which can also be fetched using getState().RawHeading), then you would have to override seedFieldCentric, resetRotation, and resetPose to all adjust the Pigeon 2 yaw and make sure that takes effect before calling the super implementation. However, I would recommend against using the Pigeon 2 yaw directly when possible. Regardless, an example is shown below.

/**
 * Blocking operation to reset the Pigeon 2 yaw to
 * the given heading. The odometry heading must be
 * updated after calling this function.
 *
 * @param heading The new heading of the Pigeon 2
 */
private void resetPigeonYaw(Rotation2d heading) {
    // reset the yaw of the Pigeon 2
    getPigeon2().setYaw(heading.getDegrees());
    // wait until we get the updated yaw
    getPigeon2().getYaw(false).waitForUpdate(0.1);
}

@Override
public void seedFieldCentric() {
    resetPigeonYaw(getOperatorForwardDirection());
    super.seedFieldCentric();
}

@Override
public void resetRotation(Rotation2d rotation) {
    resetPigeonYaw(rotation);
    super.resetRotation(rotation);
}

@Override
public void resetPose(Pose2d pose) {
    resetPigeonYaw(pose.getRotation());
    super.resetPose(pose);
}
